newsitem.title: FRANCE: Prosecutor urges heavier sentence on France's Tapie.
newsitem.headline: Prosecutor urges heavier sentence on France's Tapie.

text.p: A French public prosecutor urged an appeal court on Friday to impose a heavier punishment on bankrupt business tycoon Bernard Tapie, who was given a six-month sentence for tax evasion in managing his luxury yacht.
Prosecutor Claude Fortin said the term should be raised to eight months. Tapie is already serving a separate eight-month jail term for rigging a soccer match.
The flamboyant former minister made his first public appearance since he was jailed almost two months ago at the appeal hearing which started on Thursday.
A court had previously convicted him for passing off the majestic 74-metre (245 ft), four-masted ship Phocea as a means of promoting his business, although he was its only beneficiary.
He vigorously defended himself against fraud charges.
"I am not saying we were not at fault. But to come and tell me that all this was Machiavellian and calculated is total stupidity," he told the court.

Tapie, 54, has tumbled from political and business stardom since 1993, when he rigged a league match to give his team Marseille an easy game before their successful European Cup final against AC Milan.
The $11 million yacht, which at the height of Tapie's rise to wealth and fame was moored proudly in the old port of Marseille, has been seized and is on sale.
